Frames/Cheatsheet for Future Posts

Jul 24, 2018

“Now, to get good at writing posts, I must figure out HOW to write posts in the first place.” – Kyle B to self

Welcome to my first technical blog entry! This post will function as a technical cheatsheet for how to write posts. Much of the content here is taken directly from the Jekyll post about writing docs, but I wanted to create a cheatsheet briefly summarizing what I think is the most helpful content.

I found a generic markdown cheatsheet here but some things mentioned there don’t appear to work in this specific environment. Another Jekyll-specific cheatsheet can be found here but it’s not super comprehensive– thus the need for this post here. I’ll be adding to it continuously over the next few days (probably weeks) as I learn more and more about what’s possible and as I test my markdown, so if it seems a little small or improperly formatted, you know why.

Formatting text

Comments

Inserting: code snippets

Inserting: links

These require two lines of stuff:

Inserting: pictures

Jekyll also offers powerful support for code snippets:

Check out the Jekyll docs for more info on how to get the most out of Jekyll. File all bugs/feature requests at Jekyll’s GitHub repo. If you have questions, you can ask them on Jekyll Talk.
